item.title: On-demand NSX-T Networks with vRA Cloud in VMC on AWS VS. On-Prem vSphere
item.author: Autor
item.description: ~ Este post será traducido al español próximamente ~ You can create on-demand NSX-T networks using a vRA Cloud template in a VMC on AWS environment as well as in an on-prem vSphere environment. However, there are some differences between how on-demand NSX-T networks are created in these two environments due to limitations with vRA at the time of writing this post. On-demand Network Types vRA Cloud Assembly has several on-demand network types available depending on the resource you choose.

item.title: vRA 8 + NSX-T Blog Series Part 8: Create a vRA 8 (Cloud) Blueprint with On-demand NSX-T One-Arm Load Balancer
item.author: Autor
item.description: ~ Este post será traducido al español próximamente ~ You can create a vRA Cloud blueprint to deploy machines and place them behind an on-demand NSX-T one-arm load balancer. This method creates a tier-1 router then configures load balancing services, adding virtual server, server pool, and application profile (monitor too if you want). This method should work in vRA 8.1, but I used vRA Cloud to create the demo. Below is a simplified diagram of a NSX-T one-arm load balancer.

item.title: Parte 7 de la Serie Blog vRA 8 + NSX-T: Plantilla con 'One-Arm Load Balaner' (equilibrador de carge) Existente de NSX-T
item.author: Autor
item.description: Puede crear una plantilla vRA Cloud para desplegar máquinas y ponerlas detrás de en un “one-arm load balancer” existente de NSX-T. Este proceso no crea los enrutadors lógicos bajo demanda. El proceso usa un “one-arm load balancer” existente y simplemente agregar “virtual server” (servidor virtual), “server pool” (grupo de servidores), y “application profile” (perfil de aplicación). Puede crear un “monitor” (monitor de máquina virtual) también si quiere. Este proceso funciona con vRA 8.

item.title: Considerations When Using Layer 2 Bridges for NSX-V to NSX-T Migration
item.author: Autor
item.description: ~ Este post será traducido al español próximamente ~ I recently had a customer who asked for some general feedback on their high-level plan to migrate from NSX-V to NSX-T using layer 2 bridges. Although every environment is different and the details of migration procedures should be tailored to each environment, I thought I’d share the general guidance I gave to this customer in case there are some points here that may be transferrable to other similar NSX-V to NSX-T migration plans.
